items.text: I adjust my approach quickly when circumstances change unexpectedly.
items.rationale: Directly measures behavioral flexibility in response to changing conditions, a core facet of adaptability.

items.text: When my plans fall through, I can usually come up with a good alternative on the spot.
items.rationale: Captures the ability to generate new solutions when original plans are disrupted.

items.text: I thrive in situations where the rules or expectations are unclear.
items.rationale: Comfort with ambiguity is a hallmark of high adaptability.

items.text: People describe me as someone who goes with the flow rather than resisting change.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of flexible, non-rigid behavioral style.

items.text: I find it easy to shift my mindset when I realize my current strategy isn't working.
items.rationale: Cognitive flexibility and willingness to abandon ineffective approaches.

items.text: Moving to a new city or starting a new job feels more exciting than threatening to me.
items.rationale: Positive orientation toward major life transitions reflects high adaptability.

items.text: I can function well even when my daily routine is completely disrupted.
items.rationale: Maintaining performance despite disruption is a behavioral indicator of adaptability.

items.text: When I travel to unfamiliar places, I quickly feel comfortable and oriented.
items.rationale: Rapid adjustment to novel environments is a concrete expression of adaptability.

items.text: I rarely get flustered when multiple things change at once.
items.rationale: Emotional steadiness during simultaneous changes reflects adaptive capacity.

items.text: I see unexpected obstacles as puzzles to solve rather than problems to dread.
items.rationale: Reframing obstacles positively is a cognitive hallmark of adaptability.

items.text: I've been told I'm remarkably flexible when group plans change at the last minute.
items.rationale: Social observation of flexibility in group contexts.

items.text: I can easily switch between different tasks without losing focus or motivation.
items.rationale: Task-switching ability without performance loss is a behavioral marker of adaptability.

items.text: I tend to look for the opportunity hidden in every setback.
items.rationale: While reframing setbacks relates to adaptability, this also overlaps with Emotional Resilience through positive coping.

items.text: I don't dwell on how things used to be when my life circumstances shift.
items.rationale: Letting go of the past relates to adaptability but could also reflect emotional regulation or resilience.

items.text: I bounce back quickly when a sudden change throws me off balance.
items.rationale: Bouncing back from disruption is central to both adaptability and emotional resilience; the 'sudden change' framing pulls toward adaptability but recovery language pulls toward resilience.

items.text: I can clearly identify what I'm feeling in any given moment.
items.rationale: Emotional identification is a foundational skill within emotional competence.

items.text: I know how to express my emotions in ways that are appropriate for the situation.
items.rationale: Context-appropriate emotional expression is a core component of emotional competence.

items.text: I have a rich emotional vocabulary and can describe subtle differences between feelings.
items.rationale: Emotional granularity and vocabulary are key markers of emotional competence.

items.text: I understand why I react emotionally the way I do in most situations.
items.rationale: Understanding the causes of one's emotional reactions reflects emotional self-knowledge.

items.text: I can distinguish between feeling anxious and feeling excited, even when the sensations are similar.
items.rationale: Differentiating between physiologically similar emotions demonstrates sophisticated emotional competence.

items.text: I'm skilled at communicating my emotional needs to others without being aggressive or passive.
items.rationale: Assertive emotional communication is a behavioral expression of emotional competence.

items.text: I rarely say things in the heat of the moment that I later regret.
items.rationale: Impulse control during emotional arousal reflects competent emotional functioning.

items.text: I can experience strong emotions without being overwhelmed by them.
items.rationale: Tolerating intense affect without dysregulation is a hallmark of emotional competence.

items.text: People often come to me because I seem to handle emotional situations with skill and grace.
items.rationale: Third-person recognition of emotional skill in social contexts.

items.text: I know which situations tend to trigger strong emotional reactions in me and I prepare accordingly.
items.rationale: Proactive emotional self-management based on self-knowledge reflects high competence.

items.text: I can hold space for conflicting emotions without needing to resolve them immediately.
items.rationale: Tolerance of emotional ambivalence is an advanced emotional competence skill.

items.text: I use my emotions as useful information rather than treating them as problems to eliminate.
items.rationale: Functional use of emotional data reflects mature emotional competence.

items.text: I sometimes struggle to put my feelings into words, but I always know something important is happening inside me.
items.rationale: Acknowledges emotional awareness but with limited verbal expression, suggesting moderate competence; could also relate to intrapersonal intelligence.

items.text: I've learned over time how to channel my frustration into productive action.
items.rationale: Channeling emotions productively reflects competence but also overlaps with Managing Emotions.

items.text: When I feel a strong emotion, I can usually calm myself down before it affects my behavior.
items.rationale: Self-regulation of emotional intensity is central to both emotional competence and managing emotions; the emphasis on calming down pulls toward managing emotions.

items.text: Overall, I would say I handle the emotional demands of life very effectively.
items.rationale: Global self-assessment of emotional effectiveness captures the holistic nature of EQ.

items.text: I believe my ability to understand and manage emotions is one of my greatest strengths.
items.rationale: Self-identified strength in the broad domain of emotional intelligence.

items.text: I navigate both my own emotions and other people's emotions with confidence.
items.rationale: Encompasses both intrapersonal and interpersonal emotional functioning, reflecting global EQ.

items.text: My emotional skills help me succeed in most areas of my life.
items.rationale: Broad life success attributed to emotional skills captures the overarching EQ construct.

items.text: I feel emotionally intelligent compared to most people I know.
items.rationale: Direct self-comparison on the global EQ construct.

items.text: I can read a room, manage my own feelings, and respond appropriately all at the same time.
items.rationale: Simultaneous deployment of perceiving, managing, and responding captures integrated EQ.

items.text: Emotional situations that overwhelm others tend to be situations I handle well.
items.rationale: Superior emotional functioning relative to others in challenging situations reflects high global EQ.

items.text: I consistently make good decisions even when emotions are running high.
items.rationale: Decision-making quality under emotional pressure reflects integrated emotional intelligence.

items.text: People who know me well would rate my emotional intelligence as very high.
items.rationale: Informant-perspective item capturing perceived global EQ.

items.text: I am equally comfortable dealing with my own emotions and the emotions of others.
items.rationale: Balance across intra- and interpersonal emotional domains reflects holistic EQ.

items.text: My emotional awareness, regulation, and social skills all work together seamlessly.
items.rationale: Integration of multiple EI components into a unified whole is the essence of global EQ.

items.text: I would describe myself as emotionally wise beyond my years.
items.rationale: Emotional wisdom as a global self-assessment maps to overall EQ.

items.text: I feel confident that I can handle whatever emotional challenges come my way.
items.rationale: Emotional self-efficacy is related to global EQ but could also reflect emotional resilience specifically.

items.text: I rarely feel out of my depth in emotionally complex situations.
items.rationale: Comfort in emotional complexity suggests high EQ but could also map to emotional competence.

items.text: I understand my own emotions deeply and can also sense exactly what others are feeling.
items.rationale: Combines intrapersonal awareness with empathic perception; could map to Empathy or Intrapersonal Intelligence individually, but the combination reflects global EQ.

items.text: I recover from emotional setbacks more quickly than most people.
items.rationale: Speed of emotional recovery is a defining feature of emotional resilience.

items.text: Stressful events may knock me down temporarily, but they never keep me down for long.
items.rationale: Acknowledging impact while emphasizing recovery captures the essence of resilience.

items.text: I've been through difficult times that have ultimately made me emotionally stronger.
items.rationale: Post-adversity growth is a well-established component of emotional resilience.

items.text: I maintain a sense of hope even during my darkest moments.
items.rationale: Sustaining hope under adversity is a core psychological marker of resilience.

items.text: Criticism and rejection sting, but they don't define how I feel about myself.
items.rationale: Maintaining self-worth despite negative feedback reflects emotional resilience.

items.text: I don't fall apart when things go wrong—I find a way to keep going.
items.rationale: Persistence through adversity without emotional collapse is a hallmark of resilience.

items.text: After a major disappointment, I can usually regain my emotional footing within a reasonable time.
items.rationale: Timely emotional recovery from disappointment directly measures resilience.

items.text: I have an inner toughness that helps me weather emotional storms.
items.rationale: Self-perceived emotional fortitude is a direct indicator of resilience.

items.text: Even when I feel overwhelmed, I trust that the feeling will pass.
items.rationale: Confidence in the transience of negative states reflects resilient emotional processing.

items.text: My friends say I'm remarkably tough when life throws curveballs at me.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of emotional toughness under adversity.

items.text: I've learned to treat failures as temporary setbacks rather than permanent defeats.
items.rationale: Cognitive reappraisal of failure as temporary is a key resilience mechanism.

items.text: I can endure prolonged periods of stress without losing my sense of self.
items.rationale: Identity stability under chronic stress reflects deep emotional resilience.

items.text: I cope with loss by allowing myself to grieve while also looking toward the future.
items.rationale: Balanced grief processing reflects resilience but also touches on emotional competence in managing difficult emotions.

items.text: I try to find meaning in painful experiences rather than just pushing through them.
items.rationale: Meaning-making in adversity is related to resilience but also overlaps with intrapersonal intelligence and reflective processing.

items.text: When life gets chaotic, I stay calm and figure out my next move.
items.rationale: Staying calm in chaos could reflect resilience or adaptability; the emphasis on calmness under pressure pulls toward resilience, but the strategic response pulls toward adaptability.

items.text: I can feel what another person is going through even before they tell me about it.
items.rationale: Intuitive emotional attunement to others is a core feature of empathy.

items.text: When someone close to me is hurting, I feel a physical ache in my own chest.
items.rationale: Somatic empathic response reflects deep affective empathy.

items.text: I naturally put myself in other people's shoes when trying to understand their behavior.
items.rationale: Perspective-taking is a foundational cognitive empathy skill.

items.text: I get deeply moved by stories of people overcoming hardship, even if I don't know them personally.
items.rationale: Emotional resonance with strangers' experiences reflects broad empathic capacity.

items.text: I can usually tell when someone is putting on a brave face but is actually struggling inside.
items.rationale: Detecting concealed distress in others reflects empathic sensitivity.

items.text: Other people's moods are contagious to me—I absorb their joy and their sadness alike.
items.rationale: Emotional contagion is a well-documented component of affective empathy.

items.text: I find it easy to understand why someone might feel differently about a situation than I do.
items.rationale: Accepting divergent emotional perspectives reflects cognitive empathy.

items.text: When I see someone being treated unfairly, I feel a strong emotional reaction on their behalf.
items.rationale: Empathic anger or distress on behalf of others reflects moral-empathic responding.

items.text: I'm the person in my friend group who always notices when someone is quietly upset.
items.rationale: Social role as the emotionally attuned observer reflects high empathy.

items.text: I genuinely care about the emotional well-being of people I interact with, even casually.
items.rationale: Broad concern for others' emotional states reflects dispositional empathy.

items.text: Listening to someone describe a painful experience often brings tears to my eyes.
items.rationale: Visceral emotional response to others' pain narratives is a strong empathy indicator.

items.text: I try to understand the full context of someone's life before judging their choices.
items.rationale: Contextual perspective-taking before judgment reflects empathic understanding.

items.text: I sometimes take on other people's stress without realizing it until I feel drained.
items.rationale: Unconscious absorption of others' stress reflects empathy but also suggests difficulty with emotional boundaries, which could relate to managing emotions.

items.text: I'm very good at anticipating what someone needs emotionally in a conversation.
items.rationale: Anticipating emotional needs reflects empathy but also overlaps with interpersonal intelligence and relationship management.

items.text: I pick up on subtle shifts in someone's tone of voice that tell me their mood has changed.
items.rationale: Detecting vocal cues of mood change is empathic but also directly relates to perceiving emotions; the focus on detection rather than feeling pulls toward perceiving emotions.

items.text: I can navigate complex social dynamics and help groups work together effectively.
items.rationale: Facilitating group dynamics is a core expression of interpersonal intelligence.

items.text: I understand what motivates different people and can tailor my communication style accordingly.
items.rationale: Understanding others' motivations and adapting communication reflects sophisticated interpersonal intelligence.

items.text: I'm skilled at reading the unspoken rules and power dynamics in social situations.
items.rationale: Perceiving implicit social structures reflects high interpersonal intelligence.

items.text: I can usually predict how different people will react to a piece of news or a decision.
items.rationale: Predicting others' reactions demonstrates deep understanding of individual differences.

items.text: I know how to bring out the best in people by understanding their unique strengths and insecurities.
items.rationale: Leveraging knowledge of others' psychological profiles reflects interpersonal intelligence.

items.text: I'm often the person others turn to when there's a conflict that needs mediating.
items.rationale: Being sought out as a mediator reflects recognized interpersonal skill.

items.text: I can quickly assess what kind of personality someone has after a brief interaction.
items.rationale: Rapid personality assessment reflects keen interpersonal perception.

items.text: I understand that different people need different things from me in a relationship.
items.rationale: Recognizing differential relational needs reflects nuanced interpersonal understanding.

items.text: I'm good at figuring out the real reason behind someone's behavior, even when they don't state it directly.
items.rationale: Inferring hidden motivations reflects deep interpersonal insight.

items.text: I can sense when a group conversation is about to become tense and I know how to redirect it.
items.rationale: Anticipating and managing group emotional dynamics reflects interpersonal intelligence.

items.text: I have a natural ability to make people feel comfortable and understood in my presence.
items.rationale: Creating psychological safety for others reflects high interpersonal skill.

items.text: I understand that what people say and what they mean are often two different things.
items.rationale: Awareness of the gap between stated and intended meaning reflects interpersonal sophistication.

items.text: I find it easy to build rapport with almost anyone, regardless of their background.
items.rationale: Broad rapport-building reflects interpersonal intelligence but could also map to relationship management.

items.text: I can tell when someone is being genuine versus when they're performing a social role.
items.rationale: Detecting authenticity reflects interpersonal intelligence but also overlaps with perceiving emotions.

items.text: I know exactly how to comfort a friend who is going through a difficult time.
items.rationale: Knowing how to comfort others reflects interpersonal intelligence but the focus on emotional support in relationships pulls toward relationship management.

items.text: I spend time reflecting on my emotional patterns and what drives them.
items.rationale: Deliberate self-reflection on emotional patterns is a core facet of intrapersonal intelligence.

items.text: I have a clear understanding of my personal values and how they influence my decisions.
items.rationale: Values clarity and its connection to decision-making reflects deep self-knowledge.

items.text: I know my emotional triggers intimately and understand where they come from in my past.
items.rationale: Understanding the developmental origins of emotional triggers reflects sophisticated intrapersonal intelligence.

items.text: I regularly check in with myself to assess how I'm really feeling beneath the surface.
items.rationale: Habitual emotional self-monitoring reflects active intrapersonal intelligence.

items.text: I can articulate my deepest fears and desires with clarity and honesty.
items.rationale: Ability to access and articulate core psychological content reflects high intrapersonal intelligence.

items.text: I understand how my childhood experiences have shaped my emotional responses as an adult.
items.rationale: Developmental self-insight connecting past to present emotional functioning.

items.text: I'm honest with myself about my weaknesses and areas where I need to grow emotionally.
items.rationale: Emotional self-honesty about limitations reflects mature intrapersonal intelligence.

items.text: I have a strong sense of who I am that doesn't waver based on others' opinions.
items.rationale: Stable self-concept independent of external validation reflects deep self-knowledge.

items.text: I can trace the connection between my current mood and the specific events or thoughts that caused it.
items.rationale: Causal analysis of one's own emotional states reflects analytical intrapersonal intelligence.

items.text: I understand the difference between what I want in the moment and what truly matters to me long-term.
items.rationale: Distinguishing impulses from core values reflects sophisticated self-understanding.

items.text: Journaling or self-reflection helps me understand my inner emotional life more deeply.
items.rationale: Using reflective practices for emotional self-understanding is a behavioral marker of intrapersonal intelligence.

items.text: I'm aware of the defense mechanisms I use and can catch myself when I'm being avoidant.
items.rationale: Meta-awareness of psychological defenses reflects advanced intrapersonal intelligence.

items.text: I know what kinds of environments and relationships bring out the best and worst in me.
items.rationale: Understanding environmental influences on one's functioning reflects intrapersonal intelligence but also touches on adaptability and interpersonal awareness.

items.text: I've developed a deep understanding of my own emotional needs over the years.
items.rationale: Accumulated self-knowledge about emotional needs is central to intrapersonal intelligence but could also relate to emotional competence.

items.text: I'm very aware of how my emotions affect the people around me.
items.rationale: Awareness of one's emotional impact on others bridges intrapersonal intelligence (self-awareness) and interpersonal intelligence (social awareness).

items.text: When I feel anger rising, I have specific strategies I use to keep it from escalating.
items.rationale: Deliberate use of anger regulation strategies is a direct measure of managing emotions.

items.text: I can deliberately shift my mood when I realize a negative emotion is not serving me.
items.rationale: Intentional mood modification reflects active emotional management.

items.text: I use techniques like deep breathing or mental reframing to manage my stress levels.
items.rationale: Specific regulation techniques are behavioral indicators of emotion management skill.

items.text: I know how to soothe myself when I'm feeling anxious or overwhelmed.
items.rationale: Self-soothing ability is a fundamental emotion management skill.

items.text: I can prevent a bad mood from ruining my entire day.
items.rationale: Containing negative mood spillover reflects effective emotion management.

items.text: When I notice I'm spiraling into worry, I can usually interrupt the cycle.
items.rationale: Interrupting rumination cycles is a key emotion management behavior.

items.text: I'm good at maintaining my composure in high-pressure situations.
items.rationale: Composure under pressure reflects effective real-time emotion management.

items.text: I consciously choose how to respond to provocations rather than reacting impulsively.
items.rationale: Deliberate response selection over impulsive reaction is a hallmark of emotion management.

items.text: I have a personal toolkit of coping strategies that I draw on depending on the situation.
items.rationale: Having a flexible repertoire of coping strategies reflects sophisticated emotion management.

items.text: I can talk myself through difficult emotional moments using rational self-talk.
items.rationale: Cognitive self-talk as an emotion regulation strategy directly measures managing emotions.

items.text: I rarely let jealousy or envy control my actions, even when I feel those emotions strongly.
items.rationale: Preventing specific negative emotions from driving behavior reflects emotion management.

items.text: After receiving upsetting news, I give myself time to process before making any decisions.
items.rationale: Strategic delay of decision-making during emotional arousal is an emotion management technique.

items.text: I've gotten much better at managing my emotions as I've matured.
items.rationale: Developmental improvement in emotion management is relevant but also reflects general emotional competence growth.

items.text: I try not to suppress my emotions but rather to process them in a healthy way.
items.rationale: Healthy processing versus suppression reflects managing emotions but also touches on emotional competence and intrapersonal intelligence.

items.text: I can stay emotionally balanced even when the people around me are panicking.
items.rationale: Maintaining balance amid others' panic reflects emotion management but also emotional resilience; the social contagion resistance element creates ambiguity.

items.text: I can tell what someone is feeling just by looking at their facial expression.
items.rationale: Reading facial expressions is a foundational skill in emotion perception.

items.text: I notice emotional cues in people's body language that others seem to miss.
items.rationale: Superior detection of nonverbal emotional cues reflects high emotion perception ability.

items.text: I can detect tension in a room the moment I walk in, even if no one is speaking.
items.rationale: Ambient emotional detection reflects acute emotion perception skills.

items.text: I'm highly attuned to changes in someone's tone of voice that signal a shift in emotion.
items.rationale: Vocal prosody detection is a key channel for perceiving emotions.

items.text: I can usually tell when someone is lying or hiding their true feelings from me.
items.rationale: Detecting emotional deception reflects sophisticated emotion perception.

items.text: I pick up on micro-expressions that flash across people's faces in a split second.
items.rationale: Micro-expression detection is a specific and well-validated emotion perception skill.

items.text: I'm quick to notice when someone's words don't match their emotional state.
items.rationale: Detecting verbal-nonverbal incongruence is a hallmark of emotion perception.

items.text: I can read the emotional atmosphere of a meeting or gathering within the first few minutes.
items.rationale: Rapid assessment of group emotional climate reflects strong emotion perception.

items.text: I notice when someone's smile doesn't reach their eyes.
items.rationale: Distinguishing genuine from posed smiles is a specific emotion perception skill (Duchenne smile detection).

items.text: I'm sensitive to the emotional undertones in written messages, like texts or emails.
items.rationale: Detecting emotion in text-based communication reflects perception skill across modalities.

items.text: I can sense when a friend is upset even during a phone call where I can't see their face.
items.rationale: Auditory-only emotion detection demonstrates perception skill beyond visual cues.

items.text: I often notice emotional shifts in others before they are consciously aware of them themselves.
items.rationale: Detecting pre-conscious emotional states in others reflects exceptional perception ability.

items.text: I'm very observant of the small gestures people make that reveal how they're really feeling.
items.rationale: Observing revealing gestures is perception-focused but the interpretive element could overlap with interpersonal intelligence.

items.text: I can sense the mood of a crowd at a large event, like a concert or a protest.
items.rationale: Large-scale emotional perception is relevant but the collective nature makes it somewhat ambiguous with interpersonal intelligence.

items.text: When I notice someone is sad, I immediately feel drawn to understand why and offer support.
items.rationale: The initial noticing maps to perceiving emotions, but the motivation to understand and support pulls strongly toward empathy.

items.text: I invest time and energy in maintaining my important relationships.
items.rationale: Deliberate investment in relationship maintenance is a core relationship management behavior.

items.text: I know how to repair a relationship after a conflict or misunderstanding.
items.rationale: Conflict repair skill is a fundamental component of relationship management.

items.text: I'm good at giving feedback to others in a way that strengthens rather than damages our relationship.
items.rationale: Constructive feedback delivery that preserves relational bonds reflects relationship management skill.

items.text: I can navigate disagreements with loved ones without letting them escalate into damaging arguments.
items.rationale: De-escalation during interpersonal conflict is a key relationship management skill.

items.text: I make a conscious effort to show appreciation and gratitude to the people in my life.
items.rationale: Deliberate expression of appreciation is a proactive relationship management behavior.

items.text: I can influence and inspire others without resorting to manipulation or coercion.
items.rationale: Ethical influence and inspiration reflect sophisticated relationship management.

items.text: I'm skilled at building trust with new people and deepening trust with those I already know.
items.rationale: Trust-building across relationship stages is a core relationship management competency.

items.text: I know when to give someone space and when to reach out, and I usually get the timing right.
items.rationale: Calibrating relational proximity and timing reflects nuanced relationship management.

items.text: I can have difficult conversations with people without permanently damaging the relationship.
items.rationale: Managing difficult conversations while preserving relationships is a key management skill.

items.text: I actively work to resolve tensions in my relationships rather than letting them fester.
items.rationale: Proactive tension resolution reflects deliberate relationship management.

items.text: I'm good at helping two people who are in conflict find common ground.
items.rationale: Third-party conflict mediation reflects advanced relationship management ability.

items.text: I maintain a wide network of meaningful relationships across different areas of my life.
items.rationale: Sustaining a broad network of meaningful connections reflects effective relationship management.

items.text: I'm careful about how I communicate during emotionally charged moments in my relationships.
items.rationale: Careful communication during emotional moments reflects relationship management but also overlaps with managing emotions.

items.text: I try to understand my partner's or friend's perspective before defending my own position.
items.rationale: Prioritizing understanding before self-defense reflects relationship management but also empathy and interpersonal intelligence.

items.text: I understand the social dynamics in my workplace and use that understanding to collaborate effectively.
items.rationale: Understanding social dynamics maps to interpersonal intelligence, while using that understanding for collaboration maps to relationship management; the item bridges both.

items.text: I can usually pinpoint exactly what emotion I'm feeling at any given moment.
items.rationale: Directly assesses the ability to identify and label one's own emotional states, a core facet of emotional self-awareness.

items.text: I notice how my mood shifts throughout the day and can usually identify what triggered the change.
items.rationale: Reflects ongoing monitoring of emotional states and their antecedents, central to self-awareness.

items.text: When I feel uneasy in a situation, I take time to reflect on why I'm feeling that way.
items.rationale: Describes reflective processing of one's own emotional discomfort, a hallmark of self-awareness.

items.text: I am honest with myself about my emotional strengths and weaknesses.
items.rationale: Accurate self-appraisal of emotional functioning is a defining feature of self-awareness.

items.text: I recognize when my emotions are influencing my decisions before I act on them.
items.rationale: Awareness of emotional influence on cognition and behavior is a key self-awareness competency.

items.text: People who know me well would say I have a clear understanding of who I am emotionally.
items.rationale: Third-person perspective item capturing others' perception of the individual's emotional self-knowledge.

items.text: I can tell the difference between feeling anxious and feeling excited, even though they feel physically similar.
items.rationale: Fine-grained emotional differentiation reflects high emotional granularity, a component of self-awareness.

items.text: I am aware of how my emotional state affects the way I interact with others.
items.rationale: Recognizing the interpersonal impact of one's own emotions reflects self-awareness in social contexts.

items.text: I regularly check in with myself to see how I'm feeling emotionally.
items.rationale: Habitual emotional self-monitoring is a behavioral indicator of self-awareness.

items.text: I understand which situations tend to bring out strong emotions in me.
items.rationale: Knowledge of personal emotional triggers reflects accumulated self-awareness.

items.text: When I'm in a bad mood, I usually know the reason behind it.
items.rationale: Causal attribution of one's own negative emotional states is a direct measure of self-awareness.

items.text: I have a good sense of my own emotional patterns and tendencies over time.
items.rationale: Longitudinal self-knowledge of emotional patterns reflects deep self-awareness.

items.text: Sometimes I realize I've been feeling stressed only after someone else points it out to me.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored item; delayed recognition of stress could also reflect poor interoception rather than purely low self-awareness.

items.text: I find journaling helpful because it forces me to articulate what I'm actually feeling.
items.rationale: While journaling aids self-awareness, the item also taps into a coping strategy that could relate to self-management.

items.text: I notice when my emotions are starting to escalate and I pause before reacting.
items.rationale: The noticing component is self-awareness, but the pausing before reacting crosses into self-management territory.

items.text: I can calm myself down quickly when I feel angry or frustrated.
items.rationale: Emotion regulation of negative affect is a core competency of self-management.

items.text: I stay composed under pressure, even when things around me feel chaotic.
items.rationale: Maintaining emotional composure in stressful situations directly reflects self-management ability.

items.text: When I'm feeling overwhelmed, I have strategies I use to bring myself back to a balanced state.
items.rationale: Having and deploying emotion regulation strategies is a hallmark of effective self-management.

items.text: I don't let setbacks derail me emotionally for very long.
items.rationale: Emotional resilience and recovery from negative events is a key self-management outcome.

items.text: I can control my impulses even when I'm feeling very emotional.
items.rationale: Impulse control during emotional arousal is a defining feature of self-management.

items.text: I make a conscious effort not to take my frustrations out on other people.
items.rationale: Deliberate regulation of emotional expression in interpersonal contexts reflects self-management.

items.text: Even when I feel anxious, I can still focus on the task at hand.
items.rationale: Maintaining task focus despite emotional interference is a functional indicator of self-management.

items.text: I adapt my emotional responses to fit the demands of different situations.
items.rationale: Flexible emotional regulation across contexts is a sophisticated self-management skill.

items.text: I rarely say things in the heat of the moment that I later regret.
items.rationale: Behavioral restraint during emotional arousal is a direct indicator of self-management.

items.text: When I feel disappointed, I can reframe the situation to find something constructive in it.
items.rationale: Cognitive reappraisal of negative emotional experiences is a well-established self-management strategy.

items.text: I manage my stress effectively so that it doesn't build up over time.
items.rationale: Proactive stress management reflects ongoing self-management of emotional well-being.

items.text: I can delay gratification when I know it will lead to a better outcome.
items.rationale: Delay of gratification is a classic self-regulation and self-management competency.

items.text: I sometimes struggle to stay motivated when a task feels emotionally draining.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored; while it taps self-management, it could also relate to Using Emotions to sustain motivation.

items.text: I try to maintain a positive outlook even during difficult times, though it doesn't always come naturally.
items.rationale: Effortful positivity maintenance is self-management, but the hedging introduces ambiguity about actual competence level.

items.text: I channel my nervous energy into productive action rather than letting it paralyze me.
items.rationale: Channeling emotions into action overlaps with Using Emotions, though the regulation of nervousness is self-management.

items.text: I can usually tell when someone is upset, even if they haven't said anything about it.
items.rationale: Detecting unexpressed emotions in others through nonverbal cues is a core social awareness skill.

items.text: I pick up on the emotional atmosphere of a room almost immediately when I walk in.
items.rationale: Sensing group-level emotional climate reflects social awareness at the collective level.

items.text: I pay close attention to people's body language and tone of voice during conversations.
items.rationale: Attending to nonverbal emotional cues is a behavioral foundation of social awareness.

items.text: I find it easy to see things from another person's emotional perspective.
items.rationale: Empathic perspective-taking is a central component of social awareness.

items.text: I notice when someone in a group is being left out or feels uncomfortable.
items.rationale: Detecting social exclusion and discomfort in others reflects attunement to others' emotional states.

items.text: People often tell me I'm a good listener because I seem to really understand how they feel.
items.rationale: Being perceived as empathically attuned by others is a third-person validation of social awareness.

items.text: I am sensitive to the unspoken social dynamics and power structures in a group.
items.rationale: Awareness of implicit social hierarchies and dynamics is a sophisticated social awareness competency.

items.text: I can sense when a colleague is going through a tough time, even if they're trying to hide it.
items.rationale: Detecting concealed distress in others reflects high empathic accuracy, a key social awareness skill.

items.text: I naturally adjust my communication style based on the emotional state of the person I'm talking to.
items.rationale: Adapting communication to others' emotional states requires reading those states, reflecting social awareness.

items.text: I feel genuinely moved when I hear about someone else's struggles or hardships.
items.rationale: Affective empathy and emotional resonance with others' experiences is a core social awareness component.

items.text: I understand how cultural and personal backgrounds can shape the way people express their emotions.
items.rationale: Recognizing cultural variation in emotional expression reflects nuanced social awareness.

items.text: I can read between the lines when someone says they're 'fine' but clearly isn't.
items.rationale: Detecting discrepancies between verbal reports and actual emotional states is a hallmark of social awareness.

items.text: I sometimes absorb other people's emotions to the point where it affects my own mood.
items.rationale: Emotional contagion reflects high empathic sensitivity but could also indicate poor self-management of emotional boundaries.

items.text: I tend to notice when the mood in a meeting shifts, but I'm not always sure what caused it.
items.rationale: Detecting mood shifts is social awareness, but the inability to identify causes introduces ambiguity with Understanding Emotions.

items.text: I understand why certain organizational changes make people anxious, even when the changes seem logical.
items.rationale: Understanding the emotional impact of events on others blends social awareness with Understanding Emotions.

items.text: I understand how different emotions can blend together to create complex feelings like bittersweet nostalgia.
items.rationale: Comprehending how emotions combine into complex affective states is a core facet of understanding emotions.

items.text: I can explain why a person might feel two contradictory emotions at the same time.
items.rationale: Understanding emotional ambivalence and mixed emotions reflects sophisticated emotional knowledge.

items.text: I know that anger often masks deeper feelings like hurt, fear, or vulnerability.
items.rationale: Understanding the layered nature of emotions and secondary vs. primary emotions is central to this factor.

items.text: I can predict how someone is likely to feel in a given situation based on what I know about emotions.
items.rationale: Predicting emotional reactions requires a mental model of how emotions work, reflecting understanding of emotions.

items.text: I understand how emotions tend to evolve over time — for example, how grief can gradually transform into acceptance.
items.rationale: Knowledge of emotional trajectories and transitions reflects deep understanding of emotional processes.

items.text: I can articulate the subtle differences between emotions like guilt, shame, and embarrassment.
items.rationale: Differentiating between closely related emotions requires a rich emotional vocabulary and conceptual understanding.

items.text: I understand that the same event can trigger very different emotions in different people.
items.rationale: Recognizing individual variation in emotional appraisal reflects understanding of emotion-generating processes.

items.text: I have a good grasp of what kinds of situations typically lead to specific emotions like jealousy, pride, or contempt.
items.rationale: Knowledge of emotion-situation pairings and appraisal patterns is a core component of understanding emotions.

items.text: I understand how unresolved emotions from the past can influence a person's reactions in the present.
items.rationale: Comprehending the temporal carryover of emotional experiences reflects sophisticated emotional understanding.

items.text: I can trace the chain of emotions that leads from a minor irritation to full-blown anger.
items.rationale: Understanding emotional escalation patterns and intensity dynamics is a key aspect of this factor.

items.text: I recognize that emotions serve important functions — fear protects us, sadness signals loss, and anger signals injustice.
items.rationale: Knowledge of the functional and adaptive purposes of emotions reflects theoretical understanding of emotions.

items.text: I understand why people sometimes laugh when they're nervous or cry when they're happy.
items.rationale: Comprehending paradoxical emotional expressions reflects nuanced understanding of emotional processes.

items.text: I find it fascinating to analyze why people react emotionally the way they do.
items.rationale: While this reflects interest in emotional analysis, fascination could also reflect intellectual curiosity rather than actual competence.

items.text: I sometimes overthink emotional situations, trying to understand every nuance of what people are feeling.
items.rationale: Overthinking emotions suggests engagement with understanding them, but the rumination aspect introduces ambiguity with self-management.

items.text: When a friend describes a conflict they're having, I can usually identify the underlying emotions driving both sides.
items.rationale: Identifying others' underlying emotions in social conflicts blends understanding emotions with social awareness.

items.text: I use my enthusiasm to energize and inspire the people around me.
items.rationale: Leveraging positive emotions to motivate others is a direct application of using emotions effectively.

items.text: When I need to be creative, I know how to put myself in an emotional state that fosters new ideas.
items.rationale: Deliberately inducing emotional states to enhance cognitive processes like creativity is a core using emotions skill.

items.text: I draw on my emotions to fuel my motivation when working toward important goals.
items.rationale: Harnessing emotions as a motivational resource for goal pursuit directly reflects using emotions.

items.text: I find that my gut feelings often guide me toward good decisions.
items.rationale: Using emotional intuition as informational input for decision-making is a key aspect of using emotions.

items.text: I can tap into feelings of past successes to boost my confidence before a challenging task.
items.rationale: Deliberately accessing emotional memories to enhance performance reflects strategic use of emotions.

items.text: I use my emotional reactions as data points when evaluating a situation or making a decision.
items.rationale: Treating emotions as informational signals in judgment and decision-making is central to using emotions.

items.text: When I feel passionate about something, I channel that passion into productive work.
items.rationale: Converting emotional energy into productive output is a direct behavioral indicator of using emotions.

items.text: I know how to generate a sense of urgency in myself when I need to meet a deadline.
items.rationale: Deliberately inducing task-relevant emotional states to enhance performance reflects using emotions strategically.

items.text: My emotions help me prioritize what matters most to me in life.
items.rationale: Using emotional signals to clarify values and priorities reflects emotions as a guide for important life decisions.

items.text: I leverage my empathy to build stronger connections and collaborate more effectively with others.
items.rationale: Strategically applying emotional understanding to enhance interpersonal outcomes reflects using emotions in social contexts.

items.text: I find that experiencing a range of emotions — even negative ones — enriches my problem-solving ability.
items.rationale: Recognizing the cognitive benefits of diverse emotional experiences reflects sophisticated use of emotions.

items.text: I can shift my emotional state intentionally to match what a situation requires of me.
items.rationale: Intentional emotional state shifting for situational demands reflects active deployment of emotions as tools.

items.text: I sometimes feel strong emotions but I'm not always sure how to use them constructively.
items.rationale: Reverse-scored; acknowledges emotional experience but uncertainty about application, which could also reflect low self-management.

items.text: I trust my emotional instincts, though I sometimes wonder if I'm reading the situation correctly.
items.rationale: Trusting emotional input is using emotions, but the self-doubt introduces ambiguity with self-awareness.

items.text: I deliberately put myself in a calm, focused emotional state before making important decisions so I can think clearly.
items.rationale: Inducing calm for better decision-making blends using emotions strategically with self-management of emotional states.
